awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: AGeS2 (Awards for Geochronology Student research) Program: Democratizing access to geochronology and promoting interdisciplinary science
awd_abstract_narration:
Geochronology is profoundly important in Earth science research. Geochronology data are required to quantitatively resolve the 4th dimension of time inherent in Earth science, and are increasingly necessary to conduct modern, cutting-edge, interdisciplinary research. The growing geochronology need is accompanied by strong demands to broaden community access to geochronology data, enhance the ability of laboratories to meet this pressure, and increase community awareness of how these data are produced and interpreted. The AGeS (Awards for Geochronology Student research) program provides opportunities for graduate students to develop the scientific rationale for projects involving geochronology, and then provides them with hands-on experience actually acquiring data in labs, all while being mentored by geochronologists. This project will grow AGeS2 into a wider cross-disciplinary initiative to further enhance access to geochronology data, promote geochronology training, and stimulate new synergistic science. 

AGeS2 is aimed at 1) democratizing access to geochronology, 2) educating users of geochronology data, 3) promoting synergistic science by fostering new relationships between labs and other disciplines, and 4) providing strategic, high-quality, scientifically-valuable geochronology data for projects in which both users and producers of the data are intellectually engaged. It doubles the annual award funding for graduate student geochronology projects. A new partnership with the Geological Society of America (GSA) will allow successful management of this broader effort. AGeS2 will take advantage of new opportunities for cohort- and community building afforded by the program's popularity to maximize the educational and scientific outcomes of AGeS investments. These activities will include regular teleconferences with each year's AGeS student cohorts and two AGeS gatherings prior to the national GSA meeting. Ongoing student-lab-advisor interactions will be encouraged throughout the typical 2 year AGeS project duration to further promote project success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background
Geochronology is the scientific study of the age of Earth materials, such as rocks, minerals, and fossils. Geochronology also provides an understanding of the timing of past geological events. It is an essential sub-discipline within the Earth sciences. Geochronology is important in geological mapping, natural hazards assessment, mineral exploration, resource management, climate studies, and a number of other areas that are critical to society.

To advance this important scientific discipline, scientists from the University of Colorado, Arizona State University, and other institutions created the AGeS (Awards for Geochronology Student research) program, which is a collaborative strategy for supporting access to geochronology data and the scientific expertise of lab personnel. Starting in 2019, the AGeS program, with support from three National Science Foundation (NSF) awards (EAR-1759200, EAR-1759353, and EAR- 1759201), added the Geological Society of America (GSA) as a partner and evolved into AGeS2.

Intellectual Merit
The major goals of AGeS2 are to broaden access to geochronology, educate users of the data, promote synergistic science by fostering new relationships between labs, students, and scientists in different disciplines, and provide strategic, scientifically-valuable results for projects in which both the users and producers of the data are intellectually engaged.  

The primary portion of AGeS2, AGeS-Grad, was a competitive grant program that offered graduate students up to $10,000 to visit geochronology labs for a week or more to be trained in geochronology data acquisition and be mentored by geochronologists on a project of joint interest. These awards fill an important funding gap between small ($1,000-$3,000) student research grant opportunities (e.g., GSA graduate student research grants) and large ($100,000+ NSF grants), and can be sufficient to acquire a publishable dataset, catalyze new collaborations, and provide the foundation for future larger proposals. From 2019 through 2021, 196 graduate student submitted proposals and 52 were awarded funds.

In 2022, AGeS2 piloted a new sub-program, called AGeS-DiG (Diversity in Geochronology), with the goal of generating and testing innovative ideas to expand geochronology access for those underrepresented in the Earth sciences. This program offered awards of up to $15,000 for projects that engage underrepresented students in geochronology. AGeS-DiG received 16 proposals and provided funds to 6 awardees.

AGeS2 awardees have contributed much to the discipline of geochronology. AGeS-Grad recipients have output 6 published manuscripts and presented 45 abstracts; AGeS-DiG awardees have presented 5 abstracts. All of these AGeS2 projects involve collaborations that have helped to grow and strengthen the geochronology community. The AGeS2 website provides information about over 60 geochronology labs and more than 100 geochronology professionals; this information is a valuable resource for the geoscience community.

Broader Impacts
The AGeS2 program has generated benefits well beyond the scientific research carried out by its awardees. Each of the 196 submitted AGeS-Grad proposals (2019-2021) involved new collaborative interactions between graduate students and senior geochronologists. Graduate students who submitted AGeS2 proposals received vital practice in articulating a research problem and outlining a detailed strategy to address it. During each proposal cycle, the review committee provided feedback on every submission.

The 52 graduate students who were awarded AGeS-Grad funding have received hands-on experience acquiring and interpreting geochronology data, as well as mentoring from experts in the subject, which facilitates their training and professional development. Student awardees also got to participate in virtual and in-person meetings with the AGeS2 team. Participation in AGeS2 had a positive impact on these students? career paths. At least ten of them have completed their theses; 5 are now postdoctoral scholars, 1 is an assistant professor, 1 works for a state or federal government agency, and 3 are industry scientists.

Each of the 6 funded AGeS-DiG projects (2022) engaged underrepresented minorities in Earth science projects involving geochronology. AGeS-DiG projects engage, train, and educate students at any level (including undergraduate and community college) who have not traditionally had equal access to opportunities to be trained in geochronology methods.  Geoscience in general is well-known to be one of the least diverse scientific fields, so it is vital that geoscience and its various sub-disciplines make special efforts to engage diverse students and scientists.

Role of the Geological Society of America
GSA's major activities in supporting AGeS were: 1) maintaining and updating the AGeS2 website; 2) maintaining and updating the online AGeS2 proposal submission system; and 3) maintaining and updating the online AGeS2 proposal evaluation system. Additional activities by GSA include: 4) helping to communicate the awards and declines, as well as the reviews, to the applicants; 5) facilitating the announcement of the awardees; 6) organizing student data to facilitate program evaluation; and 7) performing some supplemental advertising and recruiting activities.
